channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: London Air Traffic Glitch Closes Airspace and Disrupts Flights
item.description: Reverberations from a malfunction Friday at a chronically troubled facility extended into continental Europe as well as some trans-Atlantic flights.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and NICOLA CLARK

item.title: Senior Afghan Official Shot Dead in Kabul, Police Say
item.description: Afghan officials say a senior official of the country’s Supreme Court has been shot dead by gunmen in the capital, Kabul.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Haitian President May Drop His Premier
item.description: To end an impasse and allow for elections, President Michel Martelly said that he would accept the recommendations of a commission that has called for the prime minister to resign.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: Ex-Chief Leads Vocal Defense of C.I.A.
item.description: The counteroffensive, which includes a new website, began even before the Senate committee issued its report on the agency’s harsh treatment of detainees.
item.dc:creator: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG and ERIC LICHTBLAU

item.title: Amid Details on Torture, Data on 26 Who Were Held in Error
item.description: Of 119 prisoners in C.I.A custody, the Senate report found that 26 were either described in the agency’s own documents as mistakenly detained, or released and given money.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mohamed Bashmilah, left, in 2008. A Senate report acknowledges Mr. Bashmilah’s 19 months of detention as wrongful.

item.title: Mexico Faces Growing Gap Between Political Class and Calls for Change
item.description: A special prosecutor to investigate corruption is expected to be named soon, but falling confidence in the president and the political process itself is imperiling the mission before it begins.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: El Pericon, Mexico, the hometown of Alexander Mora, 19, the first of 43 students missing since September whose remains have been officially identified.

item.title: World Briefing: Sudan: Prosecutor Halts Darfur Inquiry
item.description: The prosecutor of the International Criminal Court said Friday that she was suspending investigations in Darfur because no arrests had been made in a decade and the United Nations Security Council had been unwilling to use its powers to help.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS

item.title: Peru Is Indignant After Greenpeace Makes Its Mark on Ancient Site
item.description: A sign urging environmental action during a United Nations summit meeting on climate change was placed near a 1,000-year-old geoglyph that is a cultural treasure in Peru. Officials are outraged over the trespassing and the disturbance of the ancient grounds.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: A message from Greenpeace was placed near an ancient hummingbird geoglyph on Monday during a United Nations summit meeting on climate change in Peru.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Nils Usakovs, Mayor of Riga, Aims to Move Beyond Ethnic Politics
item.description: The ethnic Russian mayor of Riga, Nils Usakovs, says he hopes to put ethnic politics in the past, but the crisis in Ukraine is not helping.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We don’t talk about ethnic issues,” said Nils Usakovs, the first ethnic Russian to be elected mayor of Riga, Latvia. “I believe that, in the long run, the politics in our city and our country needs to be based on ideological values, not ethnicity.”

item.title: Korean Air Chairman Strips Daughter’s Titles After Her ‘Foolish’ Behavior
item.description: “I failed to raise her properly,” said Cho Yang-ho, chairman of Korean Air Lines, apologizing on live television as a furor over the serving of macadamia nuts continued on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Dogs in Heaven? Pope Francis Leaves Pearly Gates Open
item.description: Pope Francis’ remarks to a distraught little boy whose dog had died have caused a new debate on whether animals have souls, suffer and go to heaven.
item.category: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Pope Francis leaving St. Peter’s Basilica on Thursday. In a recent public appearance, he tried to comfort a little boy whose dog had died by saying, “Paradise is open to all of God’s creatures.”

item.title: Thai Princess, Queen-to-Be, Gives Up Title
item.description: Princess Srirasm, mother of a presumed heir to the Thai throne, lost her title after the recent arrests of her relatives and amid King Bhumibol Adulyadej’s health problems.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Energy Agency Cuts Oil Demand Forecast, Adding to Pressure on Prices
item.description: The International Energy Agency said that demand for oil in 2015 was likely to be 230,000 barrels per day less than previously predicted.
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.dc:creator: By STANLEY REED and DAVID JOLLY

item.title: Sensing a Deal on Sanctions, Iran Is Bullish
item.description: Confidence is building in Iran’s business circles, with executives in the major export industries preparing for what they see as prosperous days ahead.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Newsha Tavakolian for The New York Times
item.media:description: A shrine in Tehran. A wave of optimism in Iran began with the election of a moderate president, Hassan Rouhani, who promised to mend Iran’s ties with the world.

item.title: World Briefing: Ukraine’s President Notes Brief Calm in Conflict
item.description: President Petro O. Poroshenko said Ukraine’s military had not reported any deaths in a 24-hour period among soldiers or civilians for the first time in seven months.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Twitter Backer of ISIS Is a Clean-Cut Executive in India, British Channel Says
item.description: One of the most prolific cheerleaders for the Islamic State, @shamiwitness, is a marketing executive in Bangalore, India, Britain’s Channel 4 News said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Syrian Refugees, Once Stuck, Enter Jordan
item.description: The refugees, who had been stuck in a buffer zone along the Jordanian border for months, were granted entry, the United Nations refugee agency said.
item.dc:creator: By RANA F. SWEIS

item.title: Nurmahal Journal: Where a Holy Man Lies Frozen, Threat of a Standoff Looms
item.description: At an ashram in Punjab, followers of Ashutosh Maharaj insist that he is in a state of higher consciousness. A court disagrees, and has ordered his body cremated.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: The ashram of Ashutosh Maharaj in Nurmahal, India. State officials have ordered his cremation, but followers say he is not dead.

item.title: German Police Suspect Arson in Destruction of Refugee Shelters
item.description: The authorities said they believed that arsonists, possibly with a far-right motive, were behind the fires that destroyed three buildings near Nuremberg.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Liberal Democratic Party and Japan's Political Sclerosis
item.description: Sadly for the country, the Liberal Democrats are expected to hold on in Sunday’s national election.
item.dc:creator: By R. TAGGART MURPHY
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Corral; Photographs by Johan Ramberg/Getty Images and Mmphotos/Getty Images
